review: Because of the reviews I bought the Chromecast. I live in Australia and I was hoping to stream from my NAS. At least I was expecting to be able to use it to get US channels. I have an Apple TV, if you think that Apple is restrictive, well... Google is far worse.The Chromecast updates without asking. You just connected it on your wifi, sorry too late to root it.The DNS are hardcoded, you can forget US-block and Netflix / Hulu if you are not living in the US.At least, I could stream from my NAS? Nope, they removed the functionality.Also you are forced to install Chrome to use it. Chrome set itself as default browser without asking. Knowing the appalling Google's policy about privacy, I am not very pleased.Overall, I am very disappointed by Google, and I'll think twice before buying another of their products.
author: Poseidus

review: I'm writing this review to help someone avoid buying Chromecast for the wrong purpose.  I was hoping to use it to stream from my Samsung Galaxy Note II phone to a larger screen (TV) using my phone's data plan (which is unlimited).  Based upon everything I read here and everyone I asked (technical support), I was led to believe that the wifi needed to connect Chromecast to other devices was required strictly to network (i.e., not as THE streaming source but as a LAN).  This is not the case.  So, long story short, if you have capped internet/broadband (satellite internet, mobile hot spots, etc.) and have dreams of using your smartphone's mobile data plan with Chromecast, those dreams are unattainable with this product.If you have unlimited high-speed internet, own an older TV (that is not a "Smart TV" with built-in Wi-Fi) and would like to stream content via a computer or smartphone (or select tablets), Chromecast is great way to go.
